defs.docs: `iui`, the `i`mproved `u`ser `i`nterface crate, provides Rust bindings to `libui`, a wrapper library for native(ish) GUI libraries:

attributes.value: ! `iui`, the `i`mproved `u`ser `i`nterface crate, provides Rust bindings to `libui`, a wrapper library for native(ish) GUI libraries:
! - Win32API on Windows
! - Cocoa on Mac OS X
! - GTK+ on Linux and elsewhere
! This library exposes a Rusty procedural interface to the
! "Least Common Denominator" of GUI widgets. They are all available on all supported platforms, though some functionality may not
! perform precisely the same on all platforms. These inconsistencies are marked.
! To use the library, add the following to your `Cargo.toml`:
! ```toml
! Most of the functionality of the crate is exposed via the [UI](struct.UI.html) RAII guard, which handles all initialization and cleanup for the
! underlying library.
! After initialization, all the functionality used for creating actual UIs is in the [`controls`](controls/index.html) module.
! Fine-grained control of the event loop is avilable via the [`EventLoop`](struct.EventLoop.html) struct.
! Be aware the Cocoa (GUI toolkit on Mac OS) requires that the _first thread spawned_ controls
! the UI, so do _not_ spin off your UI interactions into an alternative thread. You're likely to
! have problems on Mac OS.
! For code examples, see the [examples](https://github.com/LeoTindall/libui-rs/blob/master/iui/examples/)
! directory.

defs.name: controls
defs.docs:
Available user interface controls and related functionality.
 
 Note that `Control` and all specific control types are references to memory which is owned by the UI library.

attributes.value: ! Available user interface controls and related functionality.
! Note that `Control` and all specific control types are references to memory which is owned by the UI library.

defs.docs: Contains a single child control and displays it and its children in a window on the screen.

defs.name: new
defs.value: fn (_ctx: &UI, title: &str, width: c_int, height: c_int, t: WindowType) -> Window
defs.docs:
Create a new window with the given title, width, height, and type.
 By default, when a new window is created, it will cause the application to quit when closed.
 The user can prevent this by adding a custom `on_closing` behavior.

attributes.value: / Create a new window with the given title, width, height, and type.
/ By default, when a new window is created, it will cause the application to quit when closed.
/ The user can prevent this by adding a custom `on_closing` behavior.

defs.name: MenuItem
defs.docs:
A `MenuItem` represents an item that is shown in a `Menu`. Note that, unlike many controls,
 the text on `MenuItem`s cannot be changed after creation.

attributes.value: / A `MenuItem` represents an item that is shown in a `Menu`. Note that, unlike many controls,
/ the text on `MenuItem`s cannot be changed after creation.

defs.name: Menu
defs.docs:
A `Menu` represents one of the top-level menus at the top of a window. As that bar is unique
 per application, creating a new `Menu` shows it on all windows that support displaying menus.

attributes.value: / A `Menu` represents one of the top-level menus at the top of a window. As that bar is unique
/ per application, creating a new `Menu` shows it on all windows that support displaying menus.

defs.name: enable
defs.docs: Enables the item, allowing it to be selected. This is the default state of a menu item.

attributes.value: / Enables the item, allowing it to be selected. This is the default state of a menu item.

defs.name: disable
defs.docs:
Disables the item, preventing it from being selected and providing a visual cue to the
 user that it cannot be selected.

attributes.value: / Disables the item, preventing it from being selected and providing a visual cue to the
/ user that it cannot be selected.

defs.name: checked
defs.docs: Returns `true` if the menu item is checked, and false if it is not checked (or not checkable).

attributes.value: / Returns `true` if the menu item is checked, and false if it is not checked (or not checkable).

defs.name: set_checked
defs.docs: Sets the menu item to either checked or unchecked based on the given value.

attributes.value: / Sets the menu item to either checked or unchecked based on the given value.
/ Setting the checked value of a non-checkable menu item has no effect.

defs.name: on_clicked
defs.docs: Sets the function to be executed when the item is clicked/selected.

attributes.value: / Sets the function to be executed when the item is clicked/selected.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Creates a new menu with the given name to be displayed in the menubar at the top of the window.

attributes.value: / Creates a new menu with the given name to be displayed in the menubar at the top of the window.

defs.name: append_item
defs.docs: Adds a new item with the given name to the menu.

attributes.value: / Adds a new item with the given name to the menu.

defs.name: append_check_item
defs.docs: Adds a new togglable (checkbox) item with the given name to the menu.

attributes.value: / Adds a new togglable (checkbox) item with the given name to the menu.

defs.name: append_separator
defs.docs: Adds a seperator to the menu.

attributes.value: / Adds a seperator to the menu.

defs.name: UI
defs.docs: A handle to user interface functionality.

attributes.value: / A handle to user interface functionality.

defs.name: init
defs.docs:
Initializes the underlying UI bindings, producing a [`UI`](struct.UI.html) struct which can be used
 to actually build your user interface. This is a reference counted type; clone it
 to get an additional reference that can be passed to, e.g., callbacks.

attributes.value: / Initializes the underlying UI bindings, producing a [`UI`](struct.UI.html) struct which can be used
/ to actually build your user interface. This is a reference counted type; clone it
/ to get an additional reference that can be passed to, e.g., callbacks.
/ Only one libUI binding can be active at once; if multiple instances are detected,
/ this function will return a [`MultipleInitError`](enum.UIError.html#variant.MultipleInitError).
/ Be aware the Cocoa (GUI toolkit on Mac OS) requires that the _first thread spawned_ controls
/ the UI, so do _not_ spin off your UI interactions into an alternative thread. You're likely to
/ have problems on Mac OS.
/ # use iui::UI;
/     let ui1 = UI::init().unwrap();
/     // This will fail because there is already an instance of UI.
/     let ui2 = UI::init();
/     assert!(ui2.is_err());
/     // ui1 dropped here.
/ let ui3 = UI::init().unwrap();
/ If libUI cannot initialize its hooks into the platform bindings, this function will
/ return a [`FailedInitError`](enum.UIError.html#variant.FailedInitError) with the description of the problem.

defs.name: main
defs.docs:
Hands control of this thread to the UI toolkit, allowing it to display the UI and respond to events.
 Does not return until the UI [quit](struct.UI.html#method.quit)s.

attributes.value: / Hands control of this thread to the UI toolkit, allowing it to display the UI and respond to events.
/ Does not return until the UI [quit](struct.UI.html#method.quit)s.
/ For more control, use the `EventLoop` struct.

defs.name: event_loop
defs.docs: Returns an `EventLoop`, a struct that allows you to step over iterations or events in the UI.

attributes.value: / Returns an `EventLoop`, a struct that allows you to step over iterations or events in the UI.

defs.name: quit
defs.docs: Running this function causes the UI to quit, exiting from [main](struct.UI.html#method.main) and no longer showing any widgets.

attributes.value: / Running this function causes the UI to quit, exiting from [main](struct.UI.html#method.main) and no longer showing any widgets.
/ Run in every window's default `on_closing` callback.

defs.name: queue_main
defs.docs:
Queues a function to be executed on the GUI threa when next possible. Returns
 immediately, not waiting for the function to be executed.

attributes.value: / Queues a function to be executed on the GUI threa when next possible. Returns
/ immediately, not waiting for the function to be executed.
/ # Example
/ use iui::prelude::*;
/ let ui = UI::init().unwrap();
/ ui.queue_main(|| { println!("Runs first") } );
/ ui.queue_main(|| { println!("Runs second") } );
/ ui.quit();

defs.name: on_should_quit
defs.docs: Set a callback to be run when the application quits.

attributes.value: / Set a callback to be run when the application quits.

defs.name: EventLoop
defs.docs:
Provides fine-grained control over the user interface event loop, exposing the `on_tick` event
 which allows integration with other event loops, custom logic on event ticks, etc.
 Be aware the Cocoa (GUI toolkit on Mac OS) requires that the _first thread spawned_ controls
 the UI, so do _not_ spin off your UI interactions into an alternative thread. You're likely to
 have problems on Mac OS.

attributes.value: / Provides fine-grained control over the user interface event loop, exposing the `on_tick` event
/ which allows integration with other event loops, custom logic on event ticks, etc.
/ Be aware the Cocoa (GUI toolkit on Mac OS) requires that the _first thread spawned_ controls
/ the UI, so do _not_ spin off your UI interactions into an alternative thread. You're likely to
/ have problems on Mac OS.

defs.name: on_tick
defs.docs:
Set the given callback to run when the event loop is executed.
 Note that if integrating other event loops you should consider
 the potential benefits and drawbacks of the various run modes.

attributes.value: / Set the given callback to run when the event loop is executed.
/ Note that if integrating other event loops you should consider
/ the potential benefits and drawbacks of the various run modes.

defs.name: next_tick
defs.docs:
Executes a tick in the event loop, returning immediately.
 The `on_tick` callback is executed after the UI step.

attributes.value: / Executes a tick in the event loop, returning immediately.
/ The `on_tick` callback is executed after the UI step.
/ Returns `true` if the application should continue running, and `false`
/ if it should quit.

defs.name: next_event_tick
defs.docs:
Hands control to the event loop until the next UI event occurs.
 The `on_tick` callback is executed after the UI step.

attributes.value: / Hands control to the event loop until the next UI event occurs.
/ The `on_tick` callback is executed after the UI step.
/ Returns `true` if the application should continue running, and `false`
/ if it should quit.

defs.name: run
defs.docs:
Hands control to the event loop until [`UI::quit()`](struct.UI.html#method.quit) is called,
 running the callback given with `on_tick` after each UI event.

attributes.value: / Hands control to the event loop until [`UI::quit()`](struct.UI.html#method.quit) is called,
/ running the callback given with `on_tick` after each UI event.

defs.name: run_delay
defs.docs:
Hands control to the event loop until [`UI::quit()`](struct.UI.html#method.quit) is called,
 running the callback given with `on_tick` approximately every
 `delay` milliseconds.

attributes.value: / Hands control to the event loop until [`UI::quit()`](struct.UI.html#method.quit) is called,
/ running the callback given with `on_tick` approximately every
/ `delay` milliseconds.

defs.name: prelude
defs.docs: Common imports are packaged into this module. It's meant to be glob-imported: `use iui::prelude::*`.

attributes.value: / Common imports are packaged into this module. It's meant to be glob-imported: `use iui::prelude::*`.
